answers.answer: There are a lot of possible contributors, but since your thyroid was removed, and the incidence of hypo patients being incorrectly medicated is so high, let's start by taking a look at your thyroid related test results and their reference ranges shown on the lab report.

Hi Gimel, thanks.  What's strange about the symptom is, it cycles.  Not persistent, I've been hypo/hyper in the past, symptoms were consistent 24/7.  This symptom, I may wake up tomorrow, condition is gone, returns in a few weeks.  That's why? I'm baffled, don't believe hormone induced.Visit urgent care in April, physician was clueless, tell's me all labs returned normal.  I have a strong feeling, it's diabetic neuropathy.  Ugent care only test TSH.  Next labs scheduled Aug 19th.  Guess, I'll just have to wait and see.TSH 1.72 (.34-5.6)

question: Hi, I never experienced any anxiety my entire life, to be honest don't know what it is.  But since I've developed diabetes, my thyroid removed, I experience a severe nervous condtion.  Believed it was diabetes, but when I check my levels, bg in normal range.  Don't know if it's anxiety or something else.  Feels like my body is being electrocuted or I drank 50 cups of coffee, an overdose of caffeine, but I don't drink caffeine.  I'll tense up really bad, all my muscles will get severly tight, occassionally my chest will hurt, from muscle tightness, other then that no pain, just super tight/stiff all over my body.  The sensation comes and goes, someday's better then others, but the nervous condition is alway's there.  Symptom is driving me nuts, I have no idea, what's causing.  Only symptom I ever have nowaday's.  Diabetic/hormone levels in normal range.  Appears my body is deficient in vitamins or something.  Seems to cycle every few weeks, like nervous condition for 3 weeks, then disappear for 3 weeks, then return.  Any idea what can cause ?  Infection, vitamin deficiency etc..... my pcp is clueless.  Thanks for any assistance.
title: Nervous condition but I'm clueless
